title: 77th Golden Globe Awards
text:
The 77th Golden Globe Awards honored the best in <a href="2019%20in%20film">film</a> and <a href="2019%20in%20American%20television">American television of 2019</a>, as chosen by the <a href="Hollywood%20Foreign%20Press%20Association">Hollywood Foreign Press Association</a>. Produced by <a href="Dick%20Clark%20Productions">Dick Clark Productions</a> and the HFPA, the ceremony was broadcast live on January 5, 2020, from <a href="The%20Beverly%20Hilton">The Beverly Hilton</a> in <a href="Beverly%20Hills%2C%20California">Beverly Hills, California</a> beginning at 5:00 p.m. <a href="Pacific%20Time%20Zone">PST</a> / 8:00 p.m. <a href="Eastern%20Time%20Zone">EST</a>. The ceremony aired live on <a href="NBC">NBC</a> in the United States. <a href="Ricky%20Gervais">Ricky Gervais</a> hosted the ceremony for the fifth and "final" time.
The nominees were announced on December 9, 2019, by <a href="Tim%20Allen">Tim Allen</a>, <a href="Dakota%20Fanning">Dakota Fanning</a> and <a href="Susan%20Kelechi%20Watson">Susan Kelechi Watson</a>. "<a href="Marriage%20Story">Marriage Story</a>" earned a leading six nominations. <a href="Tom%20Hanks">Tom Hanks</a> and <a href="Ellen%20DeGeneres">Ellen DeGeneres</a> were announced as the recipients of the <a href="Golden%20Globe%20Cecil%20B.%20DeMille%20Award">Cecil B. DeMille Award</a> and the <a href="Carol%20Burnett%20Award">Carol Burnett Award</a>, respectively.
"<a href="Once%20Upon%20a%20Time%20in%20Hollywood">Once Upon a Time in Hollywood</a>" won the most awards for the ceremony with three, including <a href="Golden%20Globe%20Award%20for%20Best%20Motion%20Picture%20%E2%80%93%20Musical%20or%20Comedy">Best Motion Picture – Musical or Comedy</a>. "<a href="1917%20%282019%20film%29">1917</a>", "<a href="Joker%20%282019%20film%29">Joker</a>", and "<a href="Rocketman%20%28film%29">Rocketman</a>" won two awards each, with "1917" winning <a href="Golden%20Globe%20Award%20for%20Best%20Motion%20Picture%20%E2%80%93%20Drama">Best Motion Picture – Drama</a>. In television, "<a href="Succession%20%28TV%20series%29">Succession</a>", "<a href="Fleabag">Fleabag</a>" and "<a href="Chernobyl%20%28miniseries%29">Chernobyl</a>" were the most awarded, with two awards each.
The ceremony was nominated for two <a href="Primetime%20Emmy%20Award">Primetime Emmy Award</a>s: <a href="Primetime%20Emmy%20Award%20for%20Outstanding%20Variety%20Special%20%28Live%29">Outstanding Variety Special (Live)</a> and <a href="Primetime%20Emmy%20Award%20for%20Outstanding%20Production%20Design%20for%20a%20Variety%20Special">Outstanding Production Design for a Variety Special</a>.

Cecil B. DeMille Award.
The <a href="Golden%20Globe%20Cecil%20B.%20DeMille%20Award">Cecil B. DeMille Award</a> is an honorary award bestowed for outstanding contributions to the world of entertainment. It is awarded to honorees who have made a significant mark in the film industry and is named after its first recipient, director <a href="Cecil%20B.%20DeMille">Cecil B. DeMille</a>.
Carol Burnett Award.
The <a href="Golden%20Globe%20Carol%20Burnett%20Award">Carol Burnett Award</a> is an honorary award given for outstanding and lasting contributions to television on or off the screen. It is named in honor of its first recipient, actress <a href="Carol%20Burnett">Carol Burnett</a>.

Controversy.
Controversy arose following <a href="Ricky%20Gervais">Ricky Gervais</a>'s opening monologue, which was seen as an attack on the hypocrisy of <a href="Cinema%20of%20the%20United%20States">Hollywood</a>. He joked about several controversial topics, such as <a href="Death%20of%20Jeffrey%20Epstein">the death</a> of <a href="Jeffrey%20Epstein">Jeffrey Epstein</a>, the <a href="2019%20college%20admissions%20bribery%20scandal">college admissions scandal</a>, and the middle-aged <a href="Leonardo%20DiCaprio">Leonardo DiCaprio</a>'s attraction to younger women. Gervais also jokingly accused the <a href="Hollywood%20Foreign%20Press%20Association">Hollywood Foreign Press</a> of <a href="racism">racism</a> for its lack of diversity in the "in memoriam" section, mocked <a href="Amazon%20%28company%29">Amazon</a>, <a href="Apple%20Inc.">Apple</a> and <a href="The%20Walt%20Disney%20Company">Disney</a> for their labor practices, and chastised awardees who talk about their political views in acceptance speeches.
Gervais's comments attained mixed reactions across the political spectrum; while <a href="Conservatism%20in%20the%20United%20States">conservatives</a> highly praised Gervais, journalists from <a href="Modern%20liberalism%20in%20the%20United%20States">liberal</a> outlets were more critical, with "<a href="Rolling%20Stone">Rolling Stone</a>" <a href="Rob%20Sheffield">Rob Sheffield</a> calling his monologue "incredibly stale". Of the criticism, Gervais said it was the "best ever", and later defended his jokes in a <a href="Twitter">tweet</a>.
